span.content: Nzumɛ́ aháŋgé mbód á abám dé eʼkɛ́.
Nzume has tethered the goat beside the fence.
snap, break off (due to weight on it)
put ladder at a steep angle
rattles worn by juju round the waist
The way he dressed is not good. His clothing got spoiled.
Only a small part of the sky is seen.
The storm removed the top of the house.
He passed along the foot path.
Go and carry water from the tap.
Place where bladder of pig is positioned.
dodder, parasite grown by putting them on other plants
medicinal plant used after miraculous escape
kind of game played with stones
put in water for soaking, to dab
He soaked the clothes in water.
He has torn it with his hands.
Áde béwanɛɛ́ nzum áhabtéd mə́ bwěm á yə̌l.
As they were fighting, he tore his clothes.
stitch, pain in the side of the abdomen
Ngáne ánə́gté mehélé mé ngíne, ahaŋ ápáŋgé mə́.
As he ran very quickly, he got stitch.
kind of medicine (taken after near loss of life)
Kɛ̌ éhɛd ahaŋ ádē ńhákē á ntyə́g-te.
Go and find the medicine which I put in the box.
Have you ever seen twin plantains?
plait, weave; make a rope out of three or more strands
He plaited a rope to use for a headband.
He rolled up the paper. / He rolled paper round the book.
Béhídɛɛ́ nkɔɔd ne ndid e etɔm.
The they plaited a rope from plantain fibres.
He put traps to catch me.
He aimed the gun at the animal.
clamp, squeeze in between, step on
He squeezed my fingers in the window.
He is cold like a corpse.
The food has no pepper/is tasteless.
The child has clung to me.
The snake is clinging onto the tree.
Touch him so that he stops speaking.
Də́ə nyaá ákíí boŋ ákōnēd muú.
Then mother left and kindled the fire.
The stream arose higher up and then ran down.
That girl is a real prostitute.
trap with large weight that kills animal (used for rats)
Alage á anɔŋ-mîn aá abum áwag mə́ áte.
He is in agony on his bed, saying his stomach hurts.
He is rough with his friends.
folding knife for shaving, razor blade
Akəə́ nló ne alen á ngəŋ.
He is using a shaving knife for shaving his hair.
to sting (of insect, scorpion), bite (of snake)
A bee will sting you there today.
Eyale tɛ́ á kálag e Dyǒb élōn.
Every word in Godʼs book will be fulfilled.
He filled the calabash with wine.
He fulfilled the promises he made.
Take more water and fill up here.
Mod aʼsó, ábe bélóntɛ́né bébɛ, nɛ̂ ábe bélóntɛ́nɛ́ béláán.
The first person, the second and then the third.
term used to form ordinal numbers
My in-law has gone to Europe/overseas.
He lay on the sick bed.
tear to pieces, tear up, tear off
The sweet yam is bad (it does not get soft no matter how long it is boiled).
The government sentenced him to death.
Blow the fire/smoke so that the porcupine comes out.
Wood with a knot is difficult to split.
He cut tattoo marks on his jaw.
The yellow yam has gone bad.
Asii á nyam ádêm ákə́lé tóma ádōŋ.
My share is bigger than yours.
Siitɛ́n ndáb ekáá á yə̌l boŋ ányên chə́.
Touch the house with your hand so that he should see it.
She soaked the shirt in water.
They argued about what they had said.
He gave his mother much trouble.
There is a lot of honey.
He has a share of meat.
to put ladder at a flat angle against something
There are a lot of leaves (on the palm branch).
bark of a certain vine, used in the production of palm wine
bark makes the palm wine strong.
Stoop down so that he will not see you.
He is red like a deer.
women on husbands side; women descended from one ancestor
kind of dance (of children in moonlight)
It is getting towards seven oʼclock.
blessing, peace (spoken accompanied by use of spittle)
small black fly that gather on stale food or dirty utensils
small black fly that is attracted by sweat (sweat bees)
Chyaá é kóm éwámsaan akwag hîn.
It thundered. / Lightning has struck. Lit.: The sky has fallen.
The stone is flat on top.
Ebíndé é mǐm ébóŋné mod awě awóó mmwaád ekɔ́ɔ́lé.
The dregs of palm wine are good for a man who has a new wife.
Alóó ndáb, eehɛ́dɛɛ́ ebom é ndáb.
He built a house without putting a proper ridge.
Ane mmwaád ahédé eboŋ á ekáá.
That woman has put a bangle on her arm.
Ahɔ́bé aá mə́kag á ahín, eʼbúúbwɔ́g éʼkóbé mə́.
He said he was going to the bush, he was afraid.
group work, work shift, work together in groups, invitation for communal work
African tulip tree; Christmas flower tree, flowers seen at the onset of the dry season
fluted pumpkin; shrub which bears a round fruit used for making gourds, and whose seeds are used in soups
a group of people moving together, gang, group
end of hen, abdomen of bird, pelvis, buttocks
The "uncles" are the ones who get the abdomen.
The sea is at Victoria (now Limbe).
tree with large fruits containing small edible seeds
basket (used in fishing, tied on the waist)
He put the fish into the basket.
A mwɛ́ɛ̄, bɛ̌ me ekaá échōŋ ńkɛɛn ályɔg.
My friend, give me your basket for going fishing.
fish container, basket for fish tied around waist
barrenness, sterility, barren woman (due to miscarriage or sickness)
fashion, being smartly dressed, showing off, moving in a certain way in nice clothes
She is someone who likes fashion.
Ekid é nzag éche tɛ́ɛ́ álə́gé.
The abandoned farm which father has left.
The shell of a snail can pierce someone.
Donʼt step on the threshold board.
inner part of raffia bamboo, raffia bamboo pith
He made the child a bamboo car.
It is difficult for us to end our hatred.
meat (from the back of the neck)
the meat from the back of the neck.
Your hatred has lasted a long time.
kind of drum, tall, a kind of
hen (which has already had chickens and so can be exchanged for a cock)
bamboo pith; inner part of raffia bamboo
The Grassfields people make doors out of raffia bamboo pith.
hen (which has already had chickens and so can be exchanged for a cock)
A razor blade cut my hand.
Eʼnɔn éʼ nyag éʼhídɛ nyag ámbīd.
The cattle egret stays around cows.
Will I get a place to sleep at your house?
The appearance of this place is good.
Epub éche étómé chǎn ébébté kaké hiîn.
Yesterdayʼs storm destroyed a lot of cocoa trees.
Nkə́ŋgé mê ḿbágé me eʼpyeeted bé nlém.
That song gave me calmness of heart.
unripe (cone or kernel of palm nuts)
Unripe kernels make a person constipated.
Ngáne nkog ńdíí ḿmén mesú, esɛ́nzɛ́ɛ adé ásē híin.
Since it is now the rainy season, the seasonal stream is very full.
He does not have enough hair.
The cane rat is feeding in the elephant grass.
large basket (carried with headband on the back) used for carrying firewood, cocoyams, etc. from the farm
The bottom of the basket is broken.
vine, bark used in the production of palm wine
Bélúmté ewúmé áyə̄le kwééd echě waáb.
They showed him respect because of his friendʼs death.
Eʼyəg ábī éʼdíɛ̄ nɛ́ɛ eʼyəg éʼ mbin.
He is red like a deer.
I have cabbage in my garden.
Haké bwěm éʼsyə̄ə̄n éʼkíne epun ehɔ́g.
Not all clothes dry the same day.
The mud wasp does not sting people.
Sébé édyɛ̂ ndyééd káa boŋ éwobpe mbeé.
Before you eat, wash up the dishes.
He bought a book which he will read.
He sent his brother a letter saying that he should come.
He has a boil under his armpit.
tree with large fruits containing small edible seeds
The chief sat in the middle.
meat from back of the neck
Kúb e nkáálé ěebooʼɛ́ á nsəl.
I brought back letters from Kumba for him.
His brother sent him a letter.
Ádê alín á máŋgole áchyáa híin.
That mango tree has borne a lot of fruits.
The clouds made the day dull.
She sent a bundle for the child.
kind of tree (whitish kernels from the fruit are used medicinally)
Sáŋgó Ntɔ́gɛɛ awagáá nɛ́ɛ muú mé ekíd é mbaŋ.
Chief Ntoko was a very effective man. Lit.: He pained like fire from palm nut shells.
a peacemaking process introduced by Ngoe
tree, produces fruits with seeds like cola nuts with white edible covering
oath (most serious one, done in Mwambong for Southern Bakossi, sworn over a file)
He got a fat belly (due to lying under oath).
dregs, heavy part (of oil or other liquid which settles to the bottom)
The meeting is in two days.
Mbomag ḿme débomɛɛ́ hɛ́n nɛ́n méesaá ngɛ̂n.
The meeting which we held here was not in vain.
wood used for making cutlass handles; the bark was used for treating wounds/sores
small trees around the house for domestic birds to pitch on
He put on a fine shirt.
Kém echě nsoosoŋge ábwémé ékone-mîn ehúné á mbwə́ŋ-sê.
The monkey which the hunter shot on the hill fell into the valley.
a peacemaking process introduced by Ngoe
He stayed in the shade with the child.
Meháŋgé ḿmē mbwɔ́g éháá me mə́ə̄ mékə́ə́ boŋ ńhâg nguu.
The towns people forced me to give a pig.
Mod awě achíbé mɔné ǎmwɛ̄ melě.
The one who stole the money will be subjected to taking an oath.
The dog oath is dangerous/very serious.
Menyiŋge médé mə́ á nlém-tê áyə̄le akudé nken ekɔ́ɔ́lé.
She was very happy because she had a newborn child.
small black fly that is attracted by sweat (sweat bees)
The meeting in the house is finished.
Mpweeted ḿmē ene mbwɛ́ ḿpwéétédé mə́ə̄ nyíēbāāʼɛ́ chə́.
That dogʼs calmness causes you not to fear it.
We will go in a short time.
Nchóŋ mə̂ ḿbédé ntâŋ aʼsó á ekɔ́ɔ̄sē.
A Grassfields man was the first slave in Bakossi.
kind of snake, Broadley’s bush viper
He does it like that animal.
Ngande eche sáá edé sú abog.
Fatherʼs feast is in nine daysʼ time.
Nzé Ngɔlɛ alií, achémɛ nɛ́ɛ ngəə.
When Ngolle is angry, he becomes wild like a leopard.
spinning top, made of wood, used as a game
They are playing with spinning tops in town.
oath (to prove innocence by taking dust from all accused, mixed in water and drunk)
Ngənɛ́ adíi eʼnɔn ábe éʼdyâg nyáké.
is a bird which eats bananas.
Ngob e dyǒb ehíné ámīn, nɛ́-əə́ mbúú ěchə̄.
The sky is black overhead, so it will rain.
A mud fish is difficult to catch in the river.
When you praise someone (for a job well done), he becomes proud, arrogant, irresponsible. (Prov. used to warn the successful against attitudes that often lead to failure.).
cuts (in which to rub medicine); tattoo cuts
tree, produces fruits with seeds like cola nuts with white edible covering
Heavy breathing is not good for a sick man.
small trees around the house for domestic birds to pitch on
wood used for making cutlass handles; the bark is used for treating wounds/sores
kind of tree, produces fruit with seeds like cola nut with white edible covering
Nsíí ńdé á nkəg mé edíb.
There is sand at the edge of the river.
They hid at the edge of the bush.
Bad bédyɛ́ɛ́ á nkin mé edíbênkwɛ̌.
People are sitting on the seashore.
long sleeved shirt as part of men’s traditional dress
enclosure trap (made in fence with a weight)
He caused the animal to fall into the trap.
old cocoyams (resulting from second and third harvest or growing on abandoned or fallow farm)
cuts (with medicine rubbed in for strength or protection)
consent fee to begin marriage procedures; acceptance (e.g., of first money given for bride price)
Akobné mə́ nkwɛntɛn aá mə́ə̄wóŋ mə́.
She has agreed to marry him.
the best/light part of palm oil rising to the top
the best/light part of palm oil rising to the top
bride price, a sum paid to the head of family who sends a girl into marriage
It was he who took the first part of the bride price.
Each person has his own blessing.
Mwǎn abídné nsambɛl ń yə̌l á ebwɔ́g.
Achané nsel mékɔ̄ɔ̄lē ḿmē áchebnɛɛ́ páá.
He bought a new file with which to sharpen the cutlass.
quarrel (resulting in not speaking to each other)
He and his brother have a quarrel.
jigger, chigger, sand flea, chigoe flea
A jigger got into my foot.
This file is a good one.
We were naked in the stream.
Ntâŋ awe béchəgɛɛ́ bán Ngaasaambɛ mə̂ ampɛɛ́n mbaaŋgé á Ekɔ́ɔ̄sē.
was the one who brought cocoyams to Bakossi.
log drum, for music and sending messages
A personʼs likeness can be found everywhere.
He is doing a repulsive thing.
The wind blew the plantain down.
kind of game (using snail shell or hard shell of cashew nut as spinning top)
It is not me who owns that house.
